thread.title: Party Time: Beyonce’s Birthday Ushers In Lowest Unemployment Since She Was 26
thread.title_full: Party Time: Beyonce’s Birthday Ushers In Lowest Unemployment Since She Was 26

title: Party Time: Beyonce’s Birthday Ushers In Lowest Unemployment Since She Was 26
text:
7 A-Rated Stocks That Pay High Dividends 
Meanwhile, labor participation continues to be flat, showing no signs that people are being enticed back into the workforce. At this point, we have to start getting used to the fact that they may not return. That's disappointing, because it would mean relatively slower growth for the country's GDP, which is no one's idea of a party. 
If this is all true, and we are at a new normal, then there is a case for the Fed to end the waiting game and raise rates. Jeff Lacker of the Richmond Fed saw it coming, giving a speech before the big day titled " The Case Against Further Delay ." 
What more is there to wait for? China and global concerns loom, but that doesn't look likely to sort itself out by December, when the Fed will most certainly be looking to make a move. However, there is still an argument that further growth could be coaxed out of this economy and that a rate hike would cut off that potential. The numbers look like what we would see in stable times, but are by no means consistent with overheating. As noted, inflation is absent, and the Beige Book had a lot of "moderate" and "modest" growth discussion with tightness only in select sectors and regions. Could keeping the interest rate at zero a few months longer get more people back into the labor force and also get stronger wage gains for workers? Is there still slack that the unemployment rate isn't capturing? 
Whatever happens, if she's a market observer, Beyonce might want to hold the vintage champagne for another birthday celebration.
